data.text: @JeffJValentine @georgehawleyUA But why?
@post_liberal @georgehawleyUA Samehere

@georgehawleyUA Nostalgia runs in 20 to 30 year cycles, so if you don't see enough of what you think should be nostalgia now, you will see it a little bit later in the next decade.  80's films still referenced the 50's fondly (like BTTF) and 80's remake/reboot mania didn't start until about 2008
@georgehawleyUA 90s were mediocre compared to the 80s. There was an electricity in the air in the 80s.

@georgehawleyUA Friends is still on TV and still praised by young viewers. We don't need a "That 90s Show" when literal shows from the 90s are alive and well. That being said, I would watch one if someone made one 💁‍♀️

@georgehawleyUA George :i was in the middle of the rave scene in the 90s "great times the ministery of sound london :non stop every weekend out sometimes 4 nights a week "some nights arrive home at 8 in the morning just to change my clothes to go to work "great times :music ☺☺☺☺

@georgehawleyUA @LindaLouMcBroom I had a nervous breakdown in the 90s.
I got divorced in the 90s.
I spent time in a homeless shelter, in the 90s
I bunked on friends' couches, in the 90s.
I (finally) bought a home of my own and then lost it to foreclosure, in the 90s.

The 90s sucked. ;)

@georgehawleyUA I hear you, but on the other hand a student showed up to my class a couple days ago wearing a stonewashed Rugrats hat, and I was like "how is it possible you even unearthed that somewhere?" which suggests to me a fairly substantial (even questionable) devotion to the 90s. :)
@georgehawleyUA Fresh off the boat.
@georgehawleyUA Fresh Off The Boat is a great 90s nostalgia show!

@georgehawleyUA Check it out, country doin' it's part. 
https://t.co/lQvwm7xlH2
@georgehawleyUA reboots happen much more quickly today.
@georgehawleyUA I don't think that demographic is driving pop culture creation https://t.co/fl95XLyvJV're right that nostalgia may be passe.

@georgehawleyUA In many respects the 1990s were especially destructive for the USA. Thanks mostly to America voting a Bonnie & Clyde combination into the White House. One a Lesbian w/ a massive lust for power. The other a Rhodes Scholar working on behalf of Rothschilds | https://t.co/ZsZae85E2s

@georgehawleyUA From my UK perspective, I would describe the 1990s as very weird and very transitional. I promote the motif the 1990s represents the start of the "New World Order".

First Gulf War, followed by the launch of NAFTA, the World Trade Organization, PNAC, and NATO bombing Yugoslavia.
@georgehawleyUA Because the 90s never ended. We're still there.

@georgehawleyUA 1920s - flappers, speakeasies and the Jazz Age
1930s- Depression and Crooners
1940s- World War II and the Big Band era
1950s- youth culture and Elvis
1960s- hippies, VietNam and the British Invasion
1970s- disco and Classic Rock
1980s- yuppies and hair bands
1990s- ?
@dpinsen @bcwaterhouse @georgehawleyUA 90s got pretty weird in a few ways. The baggy suits, the frosted tips, the Nickelodeon color schemes. Plus all the gaudy clunky new tech.
@georgehawleyUA Wasn’t Boy Meets World our Wonder Years equivalent?
@georgehawleyUA Coming in October, https://t.co/XhXQWnCj98

@stevie1666 @georgehawleyUA True. Us country folk regarded the big smoke always as an adventure. Even the bits where dodgy people were selling us blocks of wood wrapped in cling film in the park opposite the Fridge...
@stevie1666 @georgehawleyUA I dunno. The drugs were pretty good towards the end. And the music...
@georgehawleyUA Depending how long it runs, #StrangerThings might get to the 90s.
@georgehawleyUA Fresh off the boat.
@georgehawleyUA You cant have an updated version of Dazed and Confused with Hooty and the Blowfish and ‘Britpop.’

@georgehawleyUA I was born in 1980 and enjoyed a lot of the music of the 90s as I lived through it but as Ive got older and listened to more music from the 60-80s that I didnt know existed in the 90s I realise that, in retrospect, much of the music of the 90s was very derivative.
@georgehawleyUA YES

@bcwaterhouse @georgehawleyUA One issue I think is that music hasn’t changed radically in the last 20 years. More generally, the ‘90s never got crazy stylistically to be as distinctive as the ‘70s or ‘80s. Watch Heat (1995) and the clothes and hairstyles don’t look dated.
@georgehawleyUA Portland Oregon is partially 90s
@georgehawleyUA We no longer had the same shared culture in the 90s as we did in the 50s, 60s and 70s.

@cacealian @georgehawleyUA That's a gen X attitude.  We we're watching winona Ryder movies--but our younger dumber siblings were watching TGIF and having a very different experience.  
That 70s show rarely worked as nostalgia.  Worked as Teens in the Basement.
@georgehawleyUA As a kid growing up in the aughts and early teens, I’d say 90s nostalgia is indeed everywhere in online memes and fashion, as well as rap and indie rock to a great extent.
@new_suburbanist @georgehawleyUA I was gonna say this too — 90s nostalgia is very strong in the fashion industry.
@georgehawleyUA Fresh off the Boat is a 90s show
@bcwaterhouse @georgehawleyUA Yaaaaaas!! 👆🏻👆🏻👆🏻👆🏻
@georgehawleyUA Fresh Off the Boat
@bcwaterhouse @georgehawleyUA @bcwaterhouse we both replied to this separately

@georgehawleyUA I think there is a lot it's just *very online*. That plus the break up of the monoculture mean a Wonder Years isn't going to happen. Having said that, there are a few shows ostentatiously set in the 1990s like Everything Sucks  and Fresh Off The Boat

@georgehawleyUA I think the answer is that Gen X is not as grotesquely self-indulgent as the baby boomers.

Or possibly that the latter refuse to go away.
